articles.headline: Accounting for Public Pensions
articles.snippet: Pensions for government workers could soon come under the kind of scrutiny that led to the demise of private pensions.
articles.abstract: Pensions for government workers could soon come under the kind of scrutiny that led to the demise of private pensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: A generation ago, when Ronald Reagan was president, the accounting rule makers forced American companies to come clean on the cost of the pension plans they were promising to employees. That decision, perhaps more than any other, heralded the eventual demise of defined-benefit pensions for employees of American companies.

articles.headline: J.&J. Unit Issues Recall of Rolaids
articles.snippet: A Johnson & Johnson unit announced a nationwide recall of more than 13 million packages of Rolaids after reports of consumers finding metal and wood particles in the products.
articles.abstract: A Johnson & Johnson unit announced a nationwide recall of more than 13 million packages of Rolaids after reports of consumers finding metal and wood particles in the products.
articles.lead_paragraph: A unit of Johnson & Johnson announced a nationwide recall on Thursday of all lots  more than 13 million packages  of the soft chewable versions of Rolaids, its popular antacid drug, after reports of consumers finding metal and wood particles in the products.

articles.headline: After Aetna, Pondering Health Care
articles.snippet: Ronald A. Williams, who stepped down as chief executive of Aetna in November, is skeptical about what the new health care law will accomplish.
articles.abstract: Ronald A. Williams, who stepped down as chief executive of Aetna in November, is skeptical about what the new health care law will accomplish.
articles.lead_paragraph: When tensions between the Obama administration and the nation’s health insurers were at their highest earlier this year, Ronald A. Williams, the chief executive of Aetna, stood out as one of the few industry voices that still resonated within the White House.

articles.headline: On Christmas Shopping Lists, No Credit Slips
articles.snippet: More consumers are shunning credit cards for holiday shopping and using cash to keep themselves on budget.
articles.abstract: More consumers are shunning credit cards for holiday shopping and using cash to keep themselves on budget.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christmas will no longer be on credit for many shoppers, despite tempting offers from retailers and credit card companies trying to coax the plastic out of consumers’ wallets.

articles.headline: Tata’s Nano, the Car That Few Want to Buy
articles.snippet: The car intended for millions in India has been hurt by delays and safety concerns, and questions about how to cater to people of modest means.
articles.abstract: The car intended for millions in India has been hurt by delays and safety concerns, and questions about how to cater to people of modest means.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  When it was introduced in early 2009, the egg-shaped Tata Nano was billed as a modern-day people’s car, an ultracheap vehicle that would bring greater mobility to the masses of India and, eventually, the world. But those ambitions have stalled  for now, at least.

articles.headline: Obama Weighs a Broad Tax Overhaul
articles.snippet: The aim is to lower rates and raise revenues in an effort to begin addressing the growth of the national debt.
articles.abstract: The aim is to lower rates and raise revenues in an effort to begin addressing the growth of the national debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama is considering whether to push early next year for an overhaul of the income tax code to lower rates and raise revenues in what would be his first major effort to begin addressing the long-term growth of the national debt.

articles.headline: Some Unlicensed Drivers Risk More Than a Fine
articles.snippet: At least 30,000 illegal immigrants stopped in traffic cases in the last three years have ended up in deportation.
articles.abstract: At least 30,000 illegal immigrants stopped in traffic cases in the last three years have ended up in deportation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga. — It was just another suburban fender-bender. A car zoomed into an intersection and braked too late to stop at a red light. The Georgia woman driving it, an American citizen, left with a wrecked auto, a sore neck and a traffic fine.
articles.byline: By Julia Preston and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Winner’s Chair Remains Empty at Nobel Event
articles.snippet: Over China’s loud objections, the Nobel Committee honored the imprisoned dissident Liu Xiaobo in his absence.
articles.abstract: Over China’s loud objections, the Nobel Committee honored the imprisoned dissident Liu Xiaobo in his absence.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO  Imprisoned and incommunicado in China, the Chinese writer and dissident Liu Xiaobo was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, his absence marked at the prize ceremony here by an empty chair.
